sharpQuotes: A continuous reading of the original Ethics, even on a single topic, is impossible.
It is the only time, probably, dismembering a treatise actually made it more unified.
White, in his translation, uses, not altogether without reason, the stilted term 'affect' instead of the natural English term 'emotion.'
Spinoza's character, manifested in his life, has won the high admiration of every one not bitterly hostile to him.
The frugality of his life bordered on asceticism.
Spinoza lived the ethics he wrote.
In death as in life they would find him faithful to his ideal.
Spinoza was, in his own time, as the prophets were in theirs, a heretic and a rebel, a voice calling in the wildernessâ€”a wilderness that was later to become the very citadel of civilization.
To-day, after having been one of the liberating thinkers of mankind who was read but not honored, Spinoza is fast becoming one of the canonized of mankind who are honored but not read.
His philosophy, as a result, is at once the most exalted and the most matter of fact.

There is no high sentiment or glorious ideal to which Spinoza does not give proper attention and a proper place. And yet he propounds nothing in his ethical theory that cannot be clearly seen by reason and that cannot be fully substantiated by the history of man.
It must be just as possible, therefore, to apply the mathematical method to man, as it is to apply it to matter.
analysis: The extracted quotes contain memorable metaphors, compressed insights, and sharp distinctions, reflecting key elements of Spinoza's philosophy and life. They present philosophical insights sharply, and highlight the historical context and lasting influence of Spinoza's ideas, making them quotable and impactful.
